I am warning you, I was judo champion at math camp.
Alright, that is enough juvenile squabbling, stop it, stop it I say. I am going to settle this right now. Neither of you are good enough for my sister.
Who are you to decide that?
He is the man of his family, you have to respect his wishes.
You are out too, by the way.
Say what?
It is nothing personal, I’d just prefer if my future niece or nephew did not become flatulent every time they eat an Eskimo pie.
What are you so happy about?
I am not happy, it is the medication, I cannot stop smiling.
Now that Leonard’s made me aware of how high the genetic stakes are, we have to face the fact that none of you are suitable mates for my sister.
Wait a minute. Leonard made you aware of that?
We all make mistakes, let’s move on.
Excuse me, but I think you are missing a big opportunity here.
How so?
Everybody knows genetic diversity produces the strongest offspring. Why not put a little mocha in the family latte.
In principle you have a point, but as a practical matter, need I remind you that it takes experimental pharmaceuticals to simply enable you to speak to the opposite sex.
I think you are focussing entirely too much on the drugs.
Is it ‘cause I am Jewish, ‘cause I’d kill my Rabbi with a porkchop to be with your sister.
This has nothing to do with religion. This has to do with the fact that you are a tiny, tiny man who still lives with his mother.
Sheldon, you are really being unreasonable.
Am I? Here. Eat this cheese without farting and you can sleep with my sister.
Oh really?
Oops.
Shelly, can I speak to you for a minute? Alone?
Why does everyone suddenly want to talk to me alone? Usually nobody wants to be alone with me.
We all make mistakes, let’s move on.
Sheldon’s bedroom.
Okay. I am not even going to ask why you are pimping me out for cheese. But since when do you care at all about who I sleep with?
Truthfully, I have never given it any thought, but it has been pointed out to me that you carry DNA of great potential.
What on earth are you talking about?
Let me explain. You see, I am a superior genetic mutation, an improvement on the existing mediocre stock.
And what do you mean, mediocre stock?
That would be you. But residing within you is the potential for another me. Perhaps even taller, smarter and less prone to freckling, a Sheldon 2.0 if you will.
Sheldon 2.0?
Exactly. Now, I am not saying that I should be the sole decider of who you mate with. If you are not attracted to the suitor then the likelihood of conception would be reduced.
You have got to be kidding me!
Not at all. Frequent coitus dramatically increases the odds of fertiliziation.
Okay Shelly, sit down. Now I have lived my whole life dealing with the fact that my twin brother is, as Mom puts it, one of God’s special little people.

I always thought I was more like a cuckoo bird. You know, a superior creature whose egg is placed in the nest of ordinary birds. Of course the newly hatched cuckoo eats all the food, leaving the ordinary siblings to starve to death. Luckily for you, that is where the metaphor ended.

I thought it ended at cuckoo. Now you listen to me, if you want to start acting like a brother who cares about me, then terrific. Bring it on. But you try one time to tell me who I should be sleeping with, and you and I are going to go round and round the way we did when we were little. Remember?
I have an alternate proposal.
Go on.
You donate eggs. We will place them in cryogenic storage. I will find an appropriate sperm donor for your eggs, have them fertilized and implanted in you, that way everybody wins.
The living room. Sheldon enters limping, holding his groin area.
Correction. Missy can date whoever she wants.
The same, later.
Look, we have to settle this.
I agree. Sheldon’s sister is hiding at Penny’s because we have all been hitting on her at the same time.
She is not hiding. She needed privacy to call her grandmother who’s apparently very sick. Oh, and then I believe she has to wash her hair.
Oh, you poor, deluded bastard.
Do not start with me dude.
You want to go again? Let’s go.
Sit down.
Okay.
If we are going to fight over Missy, let’s do it the right way. The honourable way.
And he is down!
Come on, come on, get up.
Stay down, bitch. Yeah, ha ha, natural selection at work.
I weep for humanity.
Excuse me while I go tell Missy the good news.
Ah, hey Leonard.
Hi Penny, how’s it going. Listen, that guy Mike that you were dating, is that still going on?
Uh, pretty much, why?
Nothing, just catching up. By the way, may I speak to Missy please?
Of course.
Hi, Leonard, what is up?
Well, since you are leaving tomorrow I was wondering if you’d like to go out to dinner with me?
That is so sweet. But no thanks.
Oh. You have other plans, or…?
No.
Oh. Alright uh… enjoy the rest of your evening.
Thanks. See you.
Um, here’s something we did not anticipate.
What do you want, Howard?
I am fine, thanks for asking. I have come to call on Missy.
Missy?
Hi Howard.
The amazing Howard. Do you like magic?
Not really. No.
Then you are in for a treat. Behold, an ordinary cane.
No.
Okay.
Missy?
Thank you. I apprec…. apprec…. appreeee…. oh-oh.
Oh, honey, is your medication wearing off?
Oh, hi, cutie pie. I was hoping you’d show up.
We had a dog who made a noise like that. Had to put him down.
The stairwell. Missy and Sheldon are descending.
Any news you want me to pass along to Mom?
Well, she might be interested to know that I have refocused my research from bosonic string theory to heteronic string theory.
Yeah, I will just tell her you said hey.
Okay, well, it was pleasant seeing you, other than that business with my testicles.
Come on, Shelly. I want you to know I am very proud of you.
Really?
Yup, I am always bragging to my friends about my brother the rocket scientist.
You tell people I am a rocket scientist?
Well yeah.
I am a theoretical physicist.
What is the difference?
What is the difference?
Goodbye Shelly.
My God! Why do not you just tell them I am a toll taker at the Golden Gate Bridge? Rocket scientist, how humiliating.
The Cheesecake Factory. Raj and Sheldon are arm wrestling while playing tetris. There is a cacophony of cries such as “take him down” and “he is got you, Sheldon.”
Hey, guys, guys, some of the other waitresses wanted me to ask you something.
Oh, it is called trestling.
It combines the physical strength of arm wrestling with the mental agility of tetris into the ultimate sport.
Yeah, that is terrific, but what they wanted me to ask you was to cut it the hell out. Happy birthday to you, happy birthday to you…
We might as well stop, it is a stalemate. You are beating me in tetris, but you have got the upper body strength of a Keebler Elf.
Keebler Elf? I have got your Keebler Elf right here. Okay, it is a stalemate.
So Leonard, will we be seeing you on Saturday for your free birthday cheesecake?
He cannot eat cheesecake, he is lactose intolerant.
Okay, he can have carrot cake.
What about the cream cheese frosting.
he can scrape it off.
Forget about the cake, how did you know that my birthday is Saturday?
I did your horoscope, remember, I was going to do everybody’s until Sheldon went on one of his typical psychotic rants.

For the record, that psychotic rant was a concise summation of the research of Bertram Forer, who in 1948 proved conclusively through meticulously designed experiments, that astrology is nothing but pseudo scientific hokum.
Blah blah blah, a typical Taurus. So, seriously, are we going to see you Saturday?
Oh, I do not think so.
Why not?
I do not celebrate my birthday.
Shuddup, yeah you do.
No, it is no big deal, it is just the way I was raised. My parents focussed on celebrating achievements, and being expelled from a birth canal was not considered one of them.
Uh, that is so silly.
It is actually based on very sound theories, his mother published a paper on it.
What was it called, “I hate my son and that is why he cannot have cake?”
It was obviously effective, Leonard grew up to be an experimental physicist. Perhaps if she’d also denied him Christmas he’d be a little better at it.
Thank you.
Well I love birthdays, waking up to Mom’s special French Toast breakfast, wearing the birthday king crown, playing laser tag with all my friends.
Yeah, see, that is what kids should have.
Actually that was last year.
So you have really never had a birthday party?

No. But it was okay. I mean, when I was little I’d think maybe my parents would change their mind, and surprise me with a party, like this one birthday I came home from my Cello lesson, and I saw a lot of strange cars parked out front, and when I got to the door I could hear people whispering, and I could smell German chocolate cake, which is my favourite.
And?
Uh, it turns out my grandfather had died.
Oh my God, that is terrible.
Oh, it was kind of like a birthday party. I got to see all my cousins and there was cake, so…7
That is the saddest thing I have ever heard.
You think? Go ahead, tell her about your senior prom.
Leonard is exiting the apartment.
Make sure they remember no peanuts.
Howard, every Thai restaurant in town knows you cannot eat peanuts. They see me coming they go “ah, no peanut boy!”
Hello Penny. Leonard just left.
I know. I want to talk to you.
What would we talk about? We have no overlapping areas of interest I am aware of, and you know I do not care for chit-chat.
Okay, can you just let me in.
Well alright, but I do not see this as a promising endeavour.
Okay, here’s the deal, we are going to throw Leonard a kick-ass surprise party for his birthday on Saturday.
I hardly think so, Leonard made it very clear he does not want a party.
Did someone say party?
He just does not know he wants one because he is never had one.
I suppose that is possible, but for the record, I have never had a threesome and yet I still know I want one.
Howard, here’s the difference. The possibility exists that Leonard could have a birthday party before hell freezes over.
Fine. If I do have a threesome, you cannot be part of it. I am just kidding, yes you can. Can you bring a friend?
I think a birthday party is a terrible idea. I envy Leonard for growing up without that anguish.
Anguish?

Year after year, I had to endure wearing conical hats while being forced into the crowded sweaty hell of bouncy castles, not to mention being blindfolded and spun towards a grotesque tailless donkey as the other children mocked my disorientation.
Okay, sweetie, I understand you have scars that no non-professional can heal, but nevertheless we are going to throw Leonard a birthday party.
Have I pointed out that I am extremely uncomfortable with dancing, loud music and most other forms of alcohol induced frivolity.
Nevertheless we are….
In addition I really do not think that Leonard wants a…

Okay, here’s the deal, you either help me throw Leonard a birthday party or, so help me God, I will go into your bedroom and I will unbag all of your most valuable mint condition comic books. And on one of them, you will not know which, I will draw a tiny happy face in ink.
You cannot do that, if you make a mark on a mint comic book it is no longer mint.
Sheldon, do you understand the concept of blackmail?
Well of course I… oh! Yeah, I have an idea, let’s throw Leonard a kick ass birthday party.
Howard and Raj sneak up the stairwell carrying presents. Howard knocks on Penny’s door, a combination of two knocks, two knocks, one knock. Nothing happens. He tries again. Sheldon opens the door.
That is not the secret knock. This is the secret knock.
What difference does it make?
The whole point of a secret knock is to establish a non-verbal signal to verify the identity of one’s co-conspirators.
Is that Raj and Howard?
Possibly, but unverified.
Can you just let us in.
Luckily for you this is not a nuclear reactor.
So, what did you get the birthday boy?
Well, Raj got him an awesome limited edition Dark Knight sculpture based on Alex Ross’s definitive Batman, and I got him this amazing autographed copy of the Feynman lectures on physics.
Nice. I got him a sweater.
Okay, well, he might like that, I have seen him… chilly.
Uh, Sheldon, I did not see your present.
That is because I did not bring one.
Well why not?
Do not ask.
The entire institution of gift giving makes no sense.
Too late.

Let’s say that I go out and I spend fifty dollars on you, it is a laborious activity, because I have to imagine what you need, whereas you know what you need. Now I can simplify things, just give you the fifty dollars directly and, you could give me fifty dollars on my birthday, and so on until one of us dies leaving the other one old and fifty dollars richer. And I ask you, is it worth it?
Told you not to ask.
Well, Sheldon, you are his friend. Friends give each other presents.
I accept your premise, I reject your conclusion.
Try telling him it is a non-optional social convention.
What?
Just do it.
It is a non-optional social convention.
Oh. Fair enough.
He came with a manual.

Question, how am I going to get Leonard a present before the party? I do not drive, and the only things available within walking distance are a Thai restaurant and a gas station. I suppose I could wrap up an order of mee krob and a couple of lottery scratchers.
Okay, let’s do this, um, I will drive Sheldon to get a present, and Howard, you need to get rid of Leonard for about two hours.
No problem.
And then Raj, you bring the stuff across the hall and start setting up.
What if guests show up?
Entertain them.
What if they are women?
Stare at them and make them feel uncomfortable.
The apartment. Leonard is playing an X-Box game.
Hey!
Hey.
How’s it going?
Fine.
So, listen, the New Art is showing the revised definitive cut of Blade Runner.
Seen it.
No, you have seen the 25 anniversary final cut. This one has eight seconds of previously unseen footage. They say it completely changes the tone of the film.
Oh. Pass.
Come on, afterwards there is a Q & A with Harrison Ford’s body double.
Look, I am in the Halo battle of my life here, there is this kid in Copenhagen, he has no immune system so all he does is sit in his bubble and play Halo 24/7.
Cannot you play him some other time?
Not if you believe his doctors.
Oh my God, do you smell gas.
No.

Not surprising. Penny’s emotional responses originate from the primitive portion of the brain known as the Amygdala, while speech is centred in the much more recently developed Neocortex. The former can easily overpower the latter giving scientific credence to the notion of being rendered speechless. Or maybe she just does not want to talk.

Anyway, in 1935, Erwin Schrodinger, in an attempt to explain the Copenhagen interpretation of quantum physics, he proposed an experiment where a cat is placed in a box with a sealed vial of poison that will break open at a random time. Now, since no-one knows when or if the poison has been released, until the box is opened, the cat can be thought of as both alive and dead.

Oh, come on, it is fun. Ooh! Another bump. Okay. I will say an element, and uh, you say an element whose name starts with the last letter of the one I said, okay? I will start. Helium. Now, you could say Mercury. That would give me a Y. Ooh. Very clever, that is a tough one. So I go Ytterbium, which gets you back to M. So you go Molybdenum, and I say Magnesium, you say Manganese, and I say Europium, and, and you are left with Mendelevium, and there are no more M’s because I believe that Meitnerium should still be called Ekairidium, so congratulations, you win. Do you wanna go again?
How about we just have a little quiet time now?
All right. Hmm, huh, I am sorry, I am finding your reckless nonchalance regarding the check-engine light to be very troubling.
Get out.
Well, I have to tell you that while I do have a theoretical understanding of the workings of an internal combustion engine, I am not sure I am capable of performing diagnostics.
I said, get out.
Okay. I will give it a shot.
The university cafeteria. Sheldon enters.
Oh, Leonard, there you are, I am ready to go home.
I just got here.
Good, perfect timing.
Sheldon, I told you, I only have access to the free-electron laser at night. I cannot drive you for the next few weeks.
No, you said you could not drive me to work, this is from work.
Howard, help me out here.
No, just for the fun of it, I am gonna take his side.
Now, how do you propose I get home?
How did you get here in the first place?
Penny. But I sense that is no longer an option.
Look, I need to get to the laser lab, you are just going to have to find someone else to take you home.
Oh damn, I picked the wrong side.
Howard’s motor scooter. Howard is driving, Sheldon is on the back clutching him for dear life and screaming.
Aaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaa! Oh God, not Euclid Avenue! Aaaaaaaaaaaaaa!
Raj’s car.
Why did Howard leave you in the middle of the road anyway?
We had a difference of opinion.
Over what?
Whether or not he was trying to kill me. For the record, I maintain he was. Where are you going?
I am taking you home.

Oh, but I am not going home. It is Wednesday, Wednesday is new comic book day, we have to go to the comic book store. And then we have to stop at Soup Plantation, it is creamy tomato soup day, and Radio Shack, there is a sale on triple-a batteries. Plus, we have to go to Pottery Barn and return my Star Wars sheets.
I have a better idea.
You want to go to pottery barn first?
Penny’s apartment, she opens the door, Sheldon is stood outside with his Star Wars sheets.
Can you drive me to Pottery Barn? Maybe if I turn off the night-light, I can keep the sheets.
The apartment. Sheldon enters from the bedroom area. Everyone else is present.
Good morning.
Good morning.
Sheldon, sit down.
She is in my spot. Do not look at me like that, everybody knows that my spot.
Sheldon, you know that we care about you.
And it is because we care about you that we have decided we have to speak up.
You are hurting the people around you, sweetie.
So we made you an appointment, and we want you to keep it.
Department of motor vehicles new driver handbook? But I do not have a problem.
Sheldon, you need to learn how to drive.
This madness has to stop.
Penny’s taking you to the DMV, I am going to bed.
Why Penny?
Because rock breaks scissors, goodnight.
All right, come on Sheldon.
Hold on, I have one condition.
What?
We have to stop at Pottery Barn.
Okay.
And Radio Shack.
Fine.
And the comic book store.
All right!
Ooh, I want to go to the comic book store.
I like comic books.
The DMV.
I just do not see why I need a driver’s license, Albert Einstein never had a driver’s license.
Yeah, but Albert Einstein did not make me wet myself at 40 miles an hour.
Yeah, and I never wanted to kick Albert Einstein in the nuts. You know, I gotta ask, why did not you just get a license at 16 like everybody else?
I was otherwise engaged.
Doing what?
Examining perturbative amplitudes in n=4 supersymmetric theories leading to a re-examination of the ultraviolet properties of multi-loop n=8 supergravity using modern twistor theory.
Well, how ’bout when you were 17?
Take this to the testing area, put your name at the top, sign the bottom, answer the questions, bring it back, next! Application?
I am actually more of a theorist.
The application in your hand, give it to her.
Oh.
Take this to the testing area, put your name at the top, sign the bottom, answer the questions, bring it back, next!
Excuse me, but I have some concerns about these questions.
Look at that sign up there.
Yes?
Does it say I give a damn?
No.
That is because I do not.

Just, look, see, this first question makes no sense, how many car lengths should you leave in front of you when driving? There is no possible way to answer that, a car length is not a standardized unit of measure.
Look at the sign.
Sheldon, it is C, just put down C.
I do not need your help, Penny.
Listen to that little girl, honey, put C. Next!
No, no, wait, no, hang on, look at this next question.
Sheldon, why are you arguing with the DMV?

How else are they going to learn? Look, question 2, when are roadways most slippery? Now, okay, there are three answers, none of which are correct. The correct answer is, when covered by a film of liquid sufficient to reduce the coefficient of static friction between the tire and the road to essentially zero, but not so deep as to introduce a new source of friction.
Here’s your learner’s permit. Go away.
But I am not done. I have many additional concerns about these questions.
Do not make me climb over this counter.
Come on, let’s go.
Next!
Aced it.
The apartment. Howard is setting up a large kit of high tech equipment.
Okay, that is it, let’s boot it up.
Booting.
This is a state-of-the-art simulator. I adapted it from something a friend of mine designed for the army.
Is that why I appear to be in downtown Fallujah, behind the wheel of an up-armored Humvee?
I have not configured it yet. Let’s see… Bradley tank… transport truck… Batmobile…
Ooh!
No.
Here we go, red 2006 Ford Taurus on the streets of Pasadena.
Hmmmm?
What?
Statistically, red cars are stopped by police far more often than any other colour. I do not want any hassles with the fuzz.
Fine, what colour do you want?
You know the pale blue of Luke Skywalker’s lightsaber, before it was digitally remastered?
Black it is.
Okay, now, what you want to do first is turn on the ignition and shift into drive.
I have not fastened my seat belt yet.
Okay, fasten your seat belt.
Click. Now, are there air bags?
You do not need air bags.
What if a simulated van rear-ends me?
I will hit you in the face with a pillow.
Okay, now shift into drive, pull out slowly into traffic.
Oh.
Oh.
Oh.
Watch out.
Oh God!
Watch, watch out, watch out for pedestrians!
Oh God, wait, slow, hit the brakes, hit the brakes!
Thank you.
The same, only Sheldon and Leonard are present. Sheldon is practicing. There are sounds of squealing tyres and brakes and general panic and mayhem.
Sorry… excuse me… my bad… student driver…
How did you manage to get on the second floor of the Glendale galleria?
I do not know. I was on the Pasadena freeway, I missed my exit, flew off the overpass, and one thing led to another.
Maybe you want to give it a rest and try again tomorrow.
No. I quit.
Aw, the pet store?
Remind me to compliment Wolowitz on the software, it is amazingly detailed.
So wait,you are just gonna give up?
No, I am not giving up, I never give up.
So what is it you are doing?
I am transcending the situation. I am clearly too evolved for driving.
What does that mean?
Leonard, have you ever wondered why my little toes and lateral incisors are significantly smaller than the average for someone of my size?
I wonder a lot of things about you, Sheldon, but not… not that.
Well, those are indicators that I am farther along the evolutionary scale than the average human.
No kidding.

Well, no, no, I am not going to go so far as to say that I represent a distinct new stage in humankind, you know, a Homo Novus, if you will, no, that is for anthropologists to decide. But I am convinced that the reason I cannot master the plebeian task of driving is because I am not meant to.
Yes, you are, you are meant to learn how to drive. Please learn how to drive!
No, no. Leonard, I am meant for greater things, like unraveling the mysteries of the universe, not determining when it is safe to pass a stopped school bus on a country road.
It is never safe.
Yeah, well, I know that now.
Fine. Assuming that everything you say is true, how does the biologically superior Homo Novus get to work tomorrow morning?
Homo Novus does not know.
Well, hang in there, maybe you will evolve into something with wings.
A corridor in the university. Sheldon emerges from his office in a shower cap and bathrobe. The others are turning the corner.
Good morning, gentlemen.
Hey.
Good morning. Is there some new kind of casual Friday I do not know about?
No, he lives here now.
Really? Why?
Well, since he will not take the bus and he is too evolved to drive, he decided it would be easier to just sleep in his office and shower in the radiation lab until I am finished with my experiment.
But you finished your experiment a week ago.
Yep
The cafeteria, late at night. Two cleaning ladies enter and find a plate with toast crusts.
Oh my God, again?
It must be rats.
Rats do not make toast and cut off the crust.
You saw nothing!
A lecture room at the university.

So, if any of you are considering going into experimental physics, my door is always open. Once again, I am sorry that the demonstration did not quite work out, but now we know what happens when you accidentally spill peach Snapple into a helium neon laser. Short answer is… do not. And now to tell you about the theoretical physics department is Dr. Sheldon Cooper. Dr. Cooper?
Forget it.
Excuse me. Sheldon, we both agreed to do this.
It is a waste of time. I might as well explain the laws of thermodynamics to a bunch of labradoodles.
If you do not do this, I will not take you to the comic book store.

Hello. Nice work with the laser, by the way. Looking out at your fresh young faces, I remember when I too was deciding my academic future as a lowly graduate student. Of course, I was 14, and I’d already achieved more than most of you could ever hope to, despite my 9 o’clock bedtime. Now, there may be one or two of you in this room who has what it takes to succeed in theoretical physics, although, it is more likely that you will spend your scientific careers teaching fifth graders how to make paper mache volcanoes with baking soda lava.
Oh, good God.

In short, anyone who told you that you would someday be able to make any significant contribution to physics played a cruel trick on you, a cruel trick indeed. Any questions? Of course not. I weep for the future of science. Now if you will excuse me, the latest issue of Batman is out. Come, Leonard.
Laser demonstration’s looking pretty good now, huh?
The university cafeteria.
I love this time of the year. The leaves are turning, there is a bracing chill in the air.
Plus there is a whole new crop of female grad students about to put on just enough winter weight to make them needy and vulnerable. That is right, honey, have another calzone, Daddy can wait.
Is not there a university policy against dating graduate students?
No, if you can talk to them, you can ask them out.
Damn, there is always a catch.
Hey, guys.
Hey, Leslie.
So, dumbass, I heard you made a grad student throw up last night.
The truth can indeed be a finger down the throat of those unprepared to hear it. But why should I cater to second-rate minds?
Because first-rate minds call you “dumbass”?
Oh, yeah? Well… you are a mean person.
Excuse me, Dr. Cooper, I am Ramona Nowitzki, I was at your talk last night. I think you are just brilliant.
That is the prevailing opinion.
Oh, now I am gonna throw up.
Howard Wolowitz, department of engineering, co-designer of the International Space Station’s Liquid Waste Disposal System.

Ew. Dr. Cooper, I have read everything you have published. I especially liked your paper on grand unification using string-network condensates and was wondering how you determined that three-dimensional string-nets provided a unified picture of fermions and gauge bosons?
Amazing, an intelligent labradoodle.
Woof.
The fact is I am quite close to a breakthrough in showing how neutrinos emerge from a string-net condensate.
Oh, my God, that would change the way we view the entire physical universe.
It is what I do.
You know, the Pishkin-Wolowitz Liquid Waste Disposal System is turning a few heads as well.
Again, ew. You know, I’d love to hear more about how you intend to add neutrinos. Could we get a cup of coffee sometime?
I do not drink coffee.
I do. I love me a cup of joe.
Well, it does not have to be coffee. How about dinner?
I do eat dinner.
Great. I know a terrific little Italian place.
I never eat in strange restaurants. One runs the risk of non-standard cutlery.
Excuse me?
Sheldon lives in fear of the three-tined fork.
Three tines is not a fork, three tines is a trident. Forks are for eating, tridents are for ruling the seven seas.
What if I brought food to your place?
That would be acceptable. On Mondays, I eat Thai food. Mee krob and chicken sate with extra peanut sauce from Siam Palace.
You got it. I already have your address.
What a nice girl.
Sheldon, do you have any idea what just happened?
Yes. Apparently I am getting a free dinner.
The apartment building lobby. Ramona is waiting by the lift. Penny enters.
Oh, yeah, no, this thing’s majorly out of order. See? Sorry.
That is okay. Guess I am taking the stairs.
Where you going?
Oh, are you here to see Leonard?
No, Dr. Cooper.
Dr. Sheldon Cooper?
We are having dinner.
Sheldon Cooper? Tall, thin, looks a little like a giant praying mantis?
He is cute, is not he?
Sheldon Cooper?
The apartment. Leonard opens the door, Ramona and Penny are outside.
Hi, Leonard.
Hey, Ramona. Come on in.
Thanks. Where should I put this?
Uh, the kitchen’s fine. Hey, what are you doing?
I need to see this.
Uh-huh. The viewing area’s right over there. Sheldon, your girl… date… person… Ramona’s here.
Oh, hello.
Oh, sorry I am late. I just got so caught up reading the draft of your latest paper.
Did you enjoy the humorous footnote where I illustrate mirror-symmetry by likening it to the Flash playing tennis with himself?
So funny. But the idea that you might be able to incorporate gravity, I have to tell you, I found it physically exhilarating.
My hypotheses tend to have that effect.
I am sorry I did not bring enough for your friends. I assumed we were going to be alone.
Oh, yeah. No, we were just going.
To watch, right?
No, come on, now, we are going out.
Oh, come on, we will be quiet.
Let’s go. Okay, you two, just, have a nice… whatever this is.
Okay, you guys, look, I know this is none of my business, but I just, I have to ask, what is Sheldon’s deal?
What do you mean “deal”?
You know, like what is his deal? Is it girls? Guys? Sock puppets?
Honestly, we have been operating under the assumption that he has no deal.
Come on, everybody has a deal.
Not Sheldon. Over the years, we have formulated many theories about how he might reproduce. I am an advocate of mytosis.
I am sorry?
I believe one day Sheldon will eat an enormous amount of Thai food and split into two Sheldons.
On the other hand, I think Sheldon might be the larval form of his species, and someday he will spin a cocoon and emerge two months later with moth wings and an exoskeleton.
Okay, well, thanks for the nightmares.
Hey, do you want to hang out with us?
What are you guys gonna do?
Uh…
My mom’s making a brisket tonight.
The one with the little onions? Mmm.
Yeah, I am busy, so, goodnight.
Her loss. Let’s go.
Brisket party! B-to-the-R-to-the-I-S-K… To-the-E-to-the-T… Ooh…
Do not.
The cafeteria.
Hey, are not you having breakfast?
Yes.
Are you experimenting with nutritional suppositories again?
Not in these pants.
So, how’d it go with Ramona last night?
Oh, great. She is smart, insightful and she has a very unique way of, you know, revering me.
Here’s your spinach mushroom omelette .
Thank you. Did anyone touch it?
Gloves were worn by everyone involved. I was vigilant.
Ramona pointed out that I have been wasting 20 minutes a day standing on cafeteria lines.
Time which would be better spent tackling the great physics problems of our day.
You do not tackle the big issues, Ramona. You fence with them. En garde. Riposte.
Touche.
Morning.
Ah, hey Leslie.
So, Sheldon, I see you are organizing your papers for the Smithsonian Museum of Dumbassery.
There will not be any room until they get rid of the permanent Leslie Winkle exhibit.
Oh, good one.
I see you got a grad student to fight your battles for you. I will let you keep your lunch money today.
Okay, Dr. Cooper is on the verge of a breakthrough. If you are going to stay, you will have to be respectful and quiet.
Wait for me.
So have you worked out the neutrino issue?
Well, to paraphrase Mozart, all the subatomic particles are there, I just have to put them in the right order.
You are so witty.
Are not I?
The apartment. There is a knock on the door which then opens and Penny enters.
Hey, guys, this package came for y…
Dr. Cooper is working.
Yes, I am close to a breakthrough. Ooh, it tickles
Sorry. Holy crap on a cracker.
Hey, Penny.
Hi. You know, you probably do not want to go in there.
Why? What are they doing?
You know, the only way I could explain it would be in a therapist’s office with dolls.
Hoo-boy.
Dr. Cooper’s working.
Yeah, I can see that. Sheldon, Halo night, Koothrappali’s. You coming?
Oh, yes, it is Halo night. Let me just dry my tootsies.
You are not going to Halo night.
Yes, I am. It is Wednesday. Wednesday’s Halo night.
Did not a great man once say, “Science demands nothing less than the fervent and
He did.
And who was that great man?
Me. Sorry, Leonard.
Seriously? You are not coming?
You heard her. How can I argue with me?
Okay, well, once again, you guys have a good… whatever this is.
Dr. Cooper, I have to tell you, your friends are holding you back.
I prefer to think of it as I am pulling them forward.
Halo night? A man with your intellectual gifts does not waste an evening playing video games.
He does on Wednesdays.
Not if he wants a Nobel Prize.
He does want that. Does a man with my intellectual gifts play paintball on weekends?
What do you think?
Drat.
Now shall we get back to work?
I suppose. Battlestar Galactica comes on tonight. And then never ever watch it.

To the sound of “You Can Be My Yoko Ono” by Barenaked Ladies we see 1. the guys set off for paintball while Sheldon, dressed in paintball gear, sadly waves them goodbye, 2. Ramona catch Sheldon hiding behind the shower curtain playing on a Nintendo DS, 3. Ramona remove a book Sheldon is reading to reveal a Batman comic underneath, 4. Sheldon escape the apartment in his paintball gear only to be chased back inside by Ramona returning with groceries, she finds him sitting in his underpants with his paintball helmet still on.
Outside Penny’s apartment.
Penny, Penny
Sheldon, honey, I have told you, it is a small apartment, you only have to knock one time.
Please, please, I do not have a lot of time. Look, Ramona finally dozed off, and I need you to help me get rid of her.
Get rid of her how?
I do not know, but apparently I am in some kind of relationship, and you seem to be an expert at ending them.
Excuse me?
I see man after man leaving this apartment never to return.
Okay, first of all, it is not man after man.
Dr. Cooper?!
Hide me.
Hide you?
I formally request sanctuary.
Why are not you working?
Um… she distracted me. I told you, Penny, I do not have time for your nonsense, I have important things to do.
Oh, man.
I know what is going on here.
Really? Well, then will you explain it to me?
You are in love with Dr. Cooper.
Uh, yeah, no, that is not it.
Do not try to deny it. He is a remarkable man, but you have to let him go.
Oh, gee, okay.
I know it is hard, but he is a gift to the whole world, and we cannot be selfish.
Yeah, he is a gift all right.
Sisters?
Um, sure, sisters. Holy crap on a cracker.
Leonard’s bedroom. He is asleep. There is a tapping on the wall. He wakes up.
Sheldon? What are you doing?!
It is Morse code.
Why?
So we can communicate through the wall.
We are communicating through the wall.
Yes, but the communication is not encrypted.
I do not know Morse code.
It is very simple. This is A this is C…
Sheldon, I am not going to learn Morse code at three o’clock in the morning!
All right.
Do not come in here, do not come in here, do not come in here, do not Aw! What is going on?
Shh! Ramona’s sleeping on the couch.
I know. When is she going home?
Never, that is the problem. I need your help.
What are you talking about?
I am invoking the Skynet clause of our friendship agreement.
That only applies if you need me to help you destroy an artificial intelligence you created that is taking over the Earth.
Come on! Do not nitpick!
Good night.
Shh. All right, I am invoking our bodysnatchers clause.
The bodysnatchers clause requires me to help you destroy someone we know who’s been replaced with an alien pod.
Yes. She is in the living room. Go, I will wait here.
Sheldon, what are you doing out of bed?
Now! Do it!
You know you need your sleep in order for your cognitive processing to perform at optimum levels. Now come on.
Godzilla clause?
Not unless she destroys Tokyo.
Rats.
The living room. Sheldon is surrounded by whiteboards.
I have got it! I finally reconciled the black hole information paradox with my theory of string-network condensates!
It is unbelievable! It is paradigm-altering!
And I could not have done it without you.
Oh, please, I just offered a little encouragement.
It was a lot more than that. You helped me work out the masses of all the fermions, and you pumiced my hammer toe. How can I ever repay you?
Well, would you consider naming it the Cooper-Nowitzki Theorem?
Who’s Nowitzki?
I am Nowitzki.
Oh, you want me to share credit?
Uh-huh.
Get out!
The hallway, Ramona is leaving.
Oh, hey, hi.
Oh, bite me!
Sisters?
The cafeteria. A red haired girl approaches the table.

Excuse me, Dr. Cooper, I am Kathy O’Brien. I just finished reading your paper reconciling the black hole information paradox with your theory of string-network condensates, and it just took my breath away.
Maybe when I publish it, I will include an inhaler.
Would you possibly have any time for me to pick your brain?
Let’s see, today’s Thursday. Thursday nights, I eat pizza from Giacomo’s. Sausage, mushrooms, light olives.
Great. I will bring it to your place. I have the address.
What a nice girl.
Sheldon, do you see what just happened here?
Yes, I am getting a free pizza. I am on a roll.
The living room. The guys are eating.
More Pad Thai, please.
Sheldon, you have already had four servings.
You might want to slow down a bit, buddy.
Just one more bite.
Sheldon? Sheldon, are you okay?
I am just so… full.
That is it. No more Thai food.
The apartment. The guys are playing Boggle. There is a Klingon dictionary on the table.
Time. Alright Klingons, pencils down.
Okay, I have pokh.
Have it. Got it.
Potl.
Yup. Have it. Have it.
Pukhpa.
Have it. Got it. Yup.
I have Chorrr.
Got it. Yup.
Nekhmakh.
Yeah. Yeah.
And Kreplach.
Hold on a second. Kreplach?
Yeah.
That is not Klingon, it is Yiddish for meat-filled dumpling.
Well, as it turns out, it is also a Klingon word.
Really? Define it.
Kreplach, A hearty Klingon… dumpling.
Judge’s ruling?
Bilurrrbe.
Hey, guys, I need to use your TV.
What is wrong with your TV?
I do not know, it just died, I am getting a bunch of static.
Did you pay your cable bill?
You sound just like the cable company. All right, so, shh, Tyra Banks is about to kick someone off America’s Next Top Model.
Excuse me, Penny, but we are…
No, no, do not tell her.
…playing Klingon Boggle.
Aw!
What do you mean, aw? Like she did not know we were nerds?
All right, if you must watch, then mute it with closed captions, please.
Fine.
All right, Boggle warriors, kapla’!
Look at those women.
They are gorgeous.
Oh! Worf, nice! Too bad that is a proper noun.
Oh, look, the is the future Mrs. Wolowitz. No, wait, that is the future Mrs. Wolowitz. With her head in the lap of, what a coincidence. It is the future Mrs. Wolowitz.
Yeah, and they can all move in with you and your mother, the current Mrs. Wolowitz.
Is qochbe’ spelled with a ?
Why is that Mrs. Wolowitz crying?
Oh. That is Anais, none of the other girls in the house like her.
House? What house?
They all live in a house together.
A house, where?
I do not know. Somewhere in L.A.
Wait a minute, you are telling me that I am within driving distance of a house filled with aspiring supermodels?
Yeah, I guess.
And they live together and shower together and have naked pillow fights?
Hey, wh-where are you going?
To pay my cable bill.
All right, pencils down! I have lokh, makh, and cherrrkh. Anybody got those?
The living room. Howard and Raj are staring intently at the television. Leonard enters.
Did I miss anything? Did they kick Giselle off?
Not yet, but her underwater photo shoot was an embarrassment.
Sadly, Mrs. Giselle Wolowitz is sensitive to chlorine. Lucky for her I like my fashion models pruny and bug-eyed.
Sheldon, the food’s here.
There is the house, freeze frame, freeze frame.
What are you doing?
Marking the star positions and physical landmarks so we can find the house of the supermodels.
Why?
Is not it obvious? Every week, they kick out a beautiful girl, making her feel unwanted and without self-esteem, a.k.a. the future Mrs. Howard Wolowitz.
Is my hamburger medium well?
Yes.
Dill slices, not sweet?
Yes.
Individual relish packets?
Yes.
Onion rings?
Yes.
Extra breading?
I asked.
What did they say?
No.
Did you protest?
Yes.
Vociferously?
No.
Well, then what took you so long?
Just eat.
Hey, guys, what’d I miss? What’d I miss?
Giselle’s hanging by a thread.
Oh, good, I hate her.
Then you are not invited to our wedding.
Here you go.
Thank you.
Oh, do we have to suffer through this transparently manipulative pseudo-reality again?
Yes.
You and I have a standing TV schedule which is the result of extensive debate and compromise. Any alterations except for breaking news have to be pre-approved at the weekly roommate meeting.
Put it on the agenda.
But you have to make a motion to put it on agenda.
Oh, I will make a motion, but you are not going to like it.
Fine. Mock Parliamentary procedure. At least put it on mute.
Oh, Giselle’s not getting kicked off. It is totally going to be Summer. What?
Sheldon’s onion ring. Just put it back!
It is one onion ring.
Just put it back before he comes!
No, no, no, no, I do not think that is where it was.
Okay, here he comes, deny, deny, people, wall of silence.
Who touched my…
Penny! Penny did it.
Why would you do that?
I do not know. I was hungry? What is the big deal?
The big deal is that nobody touches food on my plate.
All right. Look, I did not know, I am sorry.
Well, I am sorry, but that is your second strike.
What?
You have two strikes. Three strikes and you are out. It is a sports metaphor.
A sports metaphor?
Yes, baseball.
All right, yeah, I will play along. What was my first strike?
March 18th. You violated my rule about forwarding email humour.
I did?
The photo of the cat who wants to “has cheezburger”?
Oh, come on, everybody loves LOLcats. They are cute and they cannot spell ’cause they are cats.
I trusted you with my email address, and you betrayed that trust by sending me Internet banality, strike one. Touching my food, strike two.
